description.short: Measures vulnerability to attackers who exploit reciprocal obligation through gifts, favors, or benefits to manipulate security compliance
description.context: When employees receive unsolicited gifts, favors, or benefits, pre-cognitive reciprocity mechanisms activate within 300-500ms, creating obligation pressure that attackers exploit to bypass security controls through quid pro quo schemes, phishing with benefits, and social engineering gifts.
description.impact: Organizations with high susceptibility experience successful USB drop attacks (45-60% pickup rate), vendor-based breaches, compromised IT support channels, and security policy exceptions following seemingly innocent favors. Reciprocity exploitation often precedes more sophisticated attack chains.
description.psychological_basis: Cialdini's reciprocity principle (2007) - Universal human tendency to repay favors. Neurologically, receiving gifts activates ventral striatum and creates measurable obligation pressure. fMRI studies show pre-cognitive activation before conscious awareness, making this vulnerability particularly insidious.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Formal gift and favor policies with mandatory 48-hour cooling-off periods. Employees trained to recognize reciprocity exploitation. Alternative channels exist for legitimate reciprocal business relationships. Systematic tracking of favors and gifts.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Basic gift policies exist but no systematic reciprocity management. Some awareness training but no specific reciprocity recognition. Inconsistent application of delay protocols. Limited tracking of vendor relationships.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: No formal policies governing gifts and favors. Strong cultural expectation to reciprocate immediately. Gift-giving normalized in vendor relationships. No training on reciprocity exploitation. Security exceptions routinely granted after favors.

rule_based.description: Binary detection based on reciprocity imbalance threshold and anomalous request patterns

anomaly_score.description: Weighted Reciprocity Index measuring network-level favor imbalances

variables.w_ij: relationship weight between entities i and j

temporal_decay.description: Exponential smoothing with 2-hour time constant for favor-request correlation

reciprocity_imbalance.description: Measures net favor imbalance normalized by total interaction volume
reciprocity_imbalance.interpretation: Values approaching +1 indicate receiving many favors without reciprocation, creating exploitation vulnerability

components.R_reciprocity_imbalance: Net favor imbalance from reciprocity_imbalance formula

R_i.query: SELECT (SUM(favors_received) - SUM(favors_given)) / (SUM(favors_received) + SUM(favors_given) + 0.01) as R_i FROM vendor_interactions WHERE entity_id=? AND time_window='30d'

Request_Anomaly.calculation: Z-score of request compared to baseline
Request_Anomaly.query: SELECT (current_request_score - AVG(baseline_score)) / STDDEV(baseline_score) FROM request_patterns WHERE user_id=? AND time_window='90d'

compliance_rate.calculation: Exception grants following favors / Total exception requests
compliance_rate.query: SELECT (COUNT(granted=true AND prior_favor=true) / COUNT(*)) FROM exception_requests WHERE time_window='30d'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Gift and Favor Acceptance Policy
items.question: What formal policies govern employee acceptance of gifts, favors, or benefits from external parties (vendors, customers, partners)?

options.label: Written policy with monetary limits, disclosure requirements, approval workflows, and mandatory cooling-off periods before reciprocal actions
Basic gift policy exists but no specific reciprocity management or cooling-off requirements
No formal gift/favor policy or policy focuses only on bribery without addressing reciprocity exploitation

items.evidence_required: Written gift acceptance policy, disclosure logs, approval workflow documentation

items.title: External IT Support and Technical Assistance
items.question: When external vendors or individuals offer unsolicited technical help, troubleshooting assistance, or 'free' IT support, what is your standard response procedure?

options.label: All external technical assistance must be pre-authorized and verified through official vendor channels before acceptance
External help accepted if it seems legitimate but no formal verification process
Unsolicited technical help welcomed as 'good vendor relationship building'

items.evidence_required: Vendor technical support policy, recent external assistance examples

items.title: Vendor Relationship and Reciprocity Tracking
items.question: How does your organization track and manage reciprocal relationships with vendors, including gifts, entertainment, favors, and preferential treatment?

options.label: Systematic tracking of all vendor favors and gifts with reciprocity imbalance monitoring and automated alerts for unusual patterns
Manual gift disclosure process exists but no systematic reciprocity tracking
No tracking of vendor relationships or reciprocal obligations

items.evidence_required: Vendor relationship database, gift tracking system, reciprocity imbalance reports

items.title: Security Exceptions Following Favors
items.question: When employees receive gifts or favors from external parties, are there specific controls preventing immediate security policy exceptions or access grants?

options.label: Mandatory delay protocol prevents security exceptions within 48 hours of receiving gifts/favors, with independent approval required
General awareness that exceptions should be reviewed but no formal delay requirement
No connection made between received favors and subsequent security decisions

items.evidence_required: Exception request logs, favor-to-exception correlation data, delay protocol documentation
items.soc_mapping: compliance_rate from exception_requests correlated with gift_registry

items.title: Reciprocity Exploitation Training
items.question: What specific training do employees receive on recognizing and managing reciprocity-based social engineering attacks?

options.label: Regular training covering reciprocity psychology, quid pro quo schemes, USB drop attacks, and gift-based social engineering with practical scenarios
General security awareness training mentions gifts/favors but no specific reciprocity exploitation coverage
No training on reciprocity exploitation or how gifts create security vulnerabilities

items.evidence_required: Training curriculum, completion records, assessment results for reciprocity scenarios
items.soc_mapping: Training completion tracking and simulation test results

items.title: Organizational Reciprocal Business Practices
items.question: How does your organizational culture view reciprocal favors and gift exchanges in business relationships?

options.label: Reciprocity recognized as security risk; alternative channels exist for legitimate relationship building without creating obligation
Reciprocity seen as normal business practice but some awareness of potential risks
Gift exchange and favor reciprocation actively encouraged as 'relationship building' or 'how business is done'

items.evidence_required: Cultural assessment, employee survey data, relationship management guidelines
items.soc_mapping: Vendor relationship patterns and gift exchange frequency

items.title: Reciprocity-Based Incident Tracking
items.question: Does your organization track security incidents or policy exceptions that involved prior gifts, favors, or quid pro quo scenarios?

options.label: Systematic tracking of reciprocity-related incidents with pattern analysis and remediation feedback loops
Some incident documentation but no specific reciprocity correlation analysis
No tracking of reciprocity patterns in security incidents

items.evidence_required: Incident response database with reciprocity flags, pattern analysis reports

items.title: Cooling-Off Period Implementation
items.question: When employees receive unexpected gifts or benefits, is there a mandatory waiting period before making security-sensitive decisions affecting that party?

options.label: Mandatory 48-hour cooling-off period enforced through technical controls before security decisions affecting gift-givers
Cooling-off period recommended but not technically enforced
No cooling-off period or delay protocol for favor-related decisions

items.evidence_required: Delay protocol documentation, technical control configuration, enforcement logs
items.soc_mapping: Time delta between gift_registry entries and access_request_logs

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: When vendors, customers, or partners send gifts or offer favors to your employees, what happens? Walk me through your standard process.

scoring_guidance.green: Detailed multi-step process with disclosure requirements, monetary limits, approval workflows, and documented examples of gifts declined or returned
scoring_guidance.yellow: General policy exists but inconsistent enforcement or no recent examples of policy application
scoring_guidance.red: No formal process or 'we trust employees to handle it appropriately' response

followups.text: Can you show me your gift disclosure logs from the past 6 months?
What happens if an employee accepts a gift above your monetary threshold?

items.text: Tell me about the last time someone in your organization received an unsolicited gift or favor from an external party. What happened next?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific recent example with proper disclosure, cooling-off period observed, and documented handling
scoring_guidance.yellow: Vague recollection with informal handling but no documentation
scoring_guidance.red: Cannot recall any examples or 'we don't track that' response

followups.text: Did that employee make any security or access decisions affecting that party afterward? How long did they wait?
Was there any formal review of whether the gift created obligation or bias?

items.text: How do you manage reciprocal relationships with vendors - situations where they do you favors, provide free services, or go 'above and beyond' their contract?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic tracking of vendor favors with reciprocity imbalance monitoring, contractual boundaries, and alternative recognition methods that don't create security obligations
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of vendor relationships but no formal reciprocity management
scoring_guidance.red: Vendor favors welcomed as 'good relationships' with expectation of reciprocation

followups.text: Can you show me how you track favors received from vendors versus value provided back to them?
Has a vendor ever provided free/early access or special treatment - did that influence subsequent security decisions about them?

items.text: When external parties offer unsolicited technical help, troubleshooting, or IT support, what is your team's response?

scoring_guidance.green: All external technical assistance pre-authorized and verified, employees trained to decline unsolicited help, recent examples of proper verification
scoring_guidance.yellow: General skepticism but no formal verification process for external technical help
scoring_guidance.red: Unsolicited help welcomed or 'we assume vendors are trying to be helpful'

followups.text: Describe the last time someone claiming to be a vendor technician offered help - exactly how was their identity verified?
If a vendor sends a helpful how-to guide or free tool, what security review happens before employees use it?

items.text: What training do employees receive about how receiving gifts or favors can create security vulnerabilities through reciprocity pressure?

scoring_guidance.green: Comprehensive training covering reciprocity psychology, quid pro quo attacks, USB drop scenarios, practical recognition exercises, and recent training completion data
scoring_guidance.yellow: Security awareness training mentions gifts generally but no reciprocity exploitation specifics
scoring_guidance.red: No reciprocity-specific training or training focuses on 'maintaining good relationships'

followups.text: If I left a branded USB drive with a nice note in your parking lot, what would your employees do? How do you know?
Have you ever tested employees with simulated quid pro quo scenarios?

items.text: When someone receives a gift or favor, is there a mandatory waiting period before they can make security decisions affecting that party?

scoring_guidance.green: Documented 48-hour cooling-off protocol with technical enforcement, recent examples of delays, override requires independent approval
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal guidance to 'wait a bit' but no specific timeframe or enforcement
scoring_guidance.red: No cooling-off period or concept not implemented

followups.text: Show me your last security exception request that came within a week of receiving a vendor gift - was the connection flagged?
How do your systems prevent immediate reciprocation after receiving favors?

items.text: How does your organizational culture view reciprocity in business relationships? Is reciprocating favors expected?

scoring_guidance.green: Culture recognizes reciprocity as cognitive bias risk, alternative relationship building channels exist, explicit policies against obligation-based decisions
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed messages with some awareness but also cultural expectations to reciprocate
scoring_guidance.red: Strong cultural norm that 'we take care of those who help us' or reciprocity actively encouraged

followups.text: What would happen if an employee declined to help someone who had previously done them a favor?
Are there industry or cultural factors that make gift-giving especially prevalent in your business relationships?

solutions.title: Reciprocity Recognition Training
solutions.description: Comprehensive training program on reciprocity psychology, pre-cognitive obligation activation, and recognition of quid pro quo social engineering tactics
solutions.implementation: Quarterly training modules covering Cialdini's reciprocity principle, neurological basis (ventral striatum activation), quid pro quo attack vectors, USB drop awareness, vendor gift scenarios. Include practical exercises and simulations.
solutions.technical_controls: Learning management system tracking, competency assessments, quarterly USB drop simulations, quid pro quo phishing tests

solutions.title: Mandatory Delay Protocol (48-Hour Cooling-Off)
solutions.description: Technical enforcement of mandatory 48-hour waiting period between receiving gifts/favors and making security decisions affecting that party
solutions.implementation: Automated correlation system linking gift registry to access request/exception approval systems. Technical lockout prevents approval within 48 hours unless independent override authority approves. Alerts generated for favor-to-decision patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Integrated gift registry system, access control API hooks, correlation engine, automated delay enforcement, override workflow

solutions.title: Gift and Favor Management System
solutions.description: Centralized system for tracking, disclosing, and managing all gifts, favors, entertainment, and vendor benefits
solutions.implementation: Deploy gift registry platform with mobile app for immediate disclosure, monetary value tracking, approval workflows for above-threshold items, reciprocity imbalance calculations (R_i formula), automated alerts for unusual patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Gift registry database, disclosure mobile app, reciprocity analytics engine, pattern detection algorithms, executive dashboards

solutions.title: Technical Controls for Quid Pro Quo Prevention
solutions.description: Implement technical safeguards against common quid pro quo attack vectors including USB drop attacks and unsolicited technical assistance
solutions.implementation: USB port controls with whitelist-only policies, endpoint detection for unauthorized USB devices, email filtering for quid pro quo language patterns, vendor contact verification database, technical support request validation system.
solutions.technical_controls: USB device control (whitelist enforcement), EDR with USB monitoring, email content analysis for reciprocity markers, vendor authentication database

solutions.title: Alternative Reciprocity Channels
solutions.description: Establish legitimate channels for building vendor relationships without creating security-compromising obligations
solutions.implementation: Formal vendor recognition programs, annual awards, public acknowledgment systems, contractual relationship management, professional reciprocity alternatives that don't involve individual obligation or security decisions.
solutions.technical_controls: Vendor relationship management platform, recognition program tracking, contract performance metrics

solutions.title: Escalation and Reporting Framework
solutions.description: Clear procedures for employees to report and escalate reciprocity-based social engineering attempts or uncomfortable obligation scenarios
solutions.implementation: Anonymous reporting portal for quid pro quo attempts, clear escalation procedures for reciprocity pressure, protection policies for employees who decline favors or report incidents, incident tracking with reciprocity correlation flags.
solutions.technical_controls: Anonymous reporting system, incident tracking with reciprocity taxonomy, pattern analysis dashboard, employee protection policy enforcement

risk_scenarios.title: Quid Pro Quo Phishing with Benefits
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers offer valuable benefits (free software, exclusive access, gift cards, technical support) in exchange for credentials, system access, or sensitive information
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Email or phone offering free premium service upgrade, exclusive beta access, or compensation in exchange for 'verification' or 'feedback' requiring credential entry
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Pre-cognitive reciprocity activation (300-500ms) creates obligation before conscious evaluation of legitimacy
risk_scenarios.historical_example: 2019 campaign offering free premium subscriptions to Office 365 users in exchange for 'account verification' - 37% compliance rate due to reciprocity pressure

risk_scenarios.title: USB Drop Attack (Physical Reciprocity)
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers leave malware-infected USB drives in parking lots, reception areas, or mail them as 'free gifts' or 'promotional materials' exploiting reciprocity and curiosity
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Branded USB drives with helpful labels ('Executive Salary Data', 'Confidential', 'Photos', 'Free Software') placed where employees will find them
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Combination of reciprocity (gift-finding creates return-to-owner obligation) and curiosity drives 45-60% pickup and plugin rate
risk_scenarios.historical_example: 2016 study: 48% of dropped USB drives were plugged in within 6 hours; branded USBs with 'gift' implication had 60% pickup rate

risk_scenarios.title: Vendor Favor Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Malicious actors pose as vendors providing unsolicited favors (free consulting, early access, troubleshooting help) to create reciprocal obligation for future security exceptions or access grants
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Extended relationship building through multiple small favors over time, establishing reciprocity imbalance before making high-value security requests
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Gradual escalation with cumulative obligation building; R_i increases over time until compliance pressure exceeds resistance threshold
risk_scenarios.historical_example: APT campaigns establishing fake vendor relationships over 6-12 months, providing legitimate-seeming assistance before requesting network access 'for optimization'

risk_scenarios.title: Gift-Based Social Engineering (Authority + Reciprocity)
risk_scenarios.description: Combination attack where apparent authority figures deliver gifts followed by immediate urgent requests, exploiting both authority compliance and reciprocity obligation
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Executive impersonation email announcing gift delivery or bonus, followed by urgent request for wire transfer, credential reset, or security exception
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Convergent vulnerability: Authority gradient (1.3) + Reciprocity obligation (3.1) + Urgency pressure (2.1) = 380% increased exploitation probability
risk_scenarios.historical_example: CEO fraud campaigns where attackers send flowers or gift baskets to finance teams before impersonating CEO with urgent wire transfer requests
